head.title: Net Radio Is Already Popular; Gadget Aims to Make It Easier

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Net Radio Is Already Popular; Gadget Aims to Make It Easier

abstract.p: Using Internet to access radio stations becomes easier with new device, Acer NeWeb iRhythm; its tuner was developed by Internet radio service Sonicbox; photo (M)

block.p: At a time when an increasing number of people are listening to high-tech radio through the Internet, Sonicbox and Acer are hoping that many people will want to control the process with a gadget that looks like something from the time when radio sets were stuffed with vacuum tubes.

The device, the Art Deco-style Acer NeWeb iRhythm ($129.99), can tune in stations in 25 genres, each containing 32 Web radio stations. The iRhythm is three separate devices: a base unit that plugs into the computer, a receiver that attaches to the stereo system and a tuner, called the iM Tuner, developed by the Internet radio service Sonicbox. All the parts are connected wirelessly. But why bother with more hardware? ''It's a lot easier -- that's the bottom line,'' said David Frerichs, vice president of products for Sonicbox.

This week, Sonicbox released a lower-cost package similar to the iRhythm. The new Sonicbox K.O. ($79.99) does what the iRhythm does but does not contain the wireless link between the computer and the home stereo system.

Both the K.O. and the iRhythm, however, depend on Sonic's Web-based radio channel services. The company offers separate sets of channels for users with dial-up modems and those with high-speed connections. The K.O. and iRhythm are available from www.sonicbox.com. The iRhythm is also sold through retailers.
